categories.name: Syntax & Compilation
categories.description: Code compiles without errors, proper syntax and language conventions, appropriate use of language features relevant to Variables and Data Types, Functions/Methods, Input/Output Operations, Code Organization, Comments and Documentation, Problem Solving Approaches.

categories.name: Logic & Correctness
categories.description: Algorithm correctness, proper implementation of requirements, handles edge cases appropriately, demonstrates understanding of Variables and Data Types, Functions/Methods, Input/Output Operations, Code Organization, Comments and Documentation, Problem Solving Approaches.

categories.name: Output & Functionality
categories.description: Produces expected output format, meets all functional requirements, handles input/output correctly, demonstrates working solution.

categories.name: Style & Documentation
categories.description: Clear variable and function names, proper indentation and formatting, appropriate comments, follows coding best practices.

category_scores.reasoning: The code is syntactically correct and compiles without errors. It uses standard Java conventions and features appropriately for the problem domain.

The logic for calculating surface area and volume is correct. All methods, including constructors and getters, are implemented according to the requirements. The test program correctly instantiates and uses the `Cuboid` objects.
The `displayInfo` method correctly outputs all the required information (color, dimensions, surface area, volume) for both `Cuboid` objects. The output format matches the expected behavior.

Variable and method names are clear and follow Java conventions (e.g., `l`, `w`, `h`, `color`, `getSurfaceArea`). Indentation and formatting are consistent. No comments are present, but the code is self-explanatory given its simplicity.

feedback.overall_comment: Excellent work! The `Cuboid` class is implemented correctly and efficiently, fulfilling all requirements of the assignment. The code is clean, well-structured, and produces the exact output expected. The use of constructors, getters, and specific calculation methods demonstrates a solid understanding of object-oriented principles.
strengths: Correct implementation of both constructors, including the chained constructor.
Accurate calculation of surface area and volume.
All required getter methods are present and functional.
The `displayInfo` method provides a clear and comprehensive output.
The test program correctly creates and uses `Cuboid` objects.
Code is well-formatted and easy to read.
areas_for_improvement: Consider adding Javadoc comments to explain the purpose of the class, its attributes, and methods for better documentation, although the code is largely self-explanatory.

category_scores.reasoning: Code compiles cleanly with correct Java syntax, proper field declarations, constructor chaining, and use of standard getters. Only minor issue: no-arg constructor does not chain to the 4-arg constructor via this() as specified.

All formulas (surface area, volume) and object state management are correct. The no-arg constructor sets fields directly instead of delegating via this(1,1,1,'white'), which deviates from the explicit requirement. Otherwise logic is sound.
Program produces the expected four-line output per object with correct labels and calculated values; meets functional requirements.
Identifiers are clear, indentation consistent, but class and methods lack JavaDoc/comments. Missing explicit @Override or final modifiers, yet overall readable.

feedback.overall_comment: A solid submission that compiles and runs correctly. Minor deviation from the constructor-chaining requirement and absence of documentation are the only notable gaps.
strengths: Clean, idiomatic Java syntax with private fields and public getters.
Correct mathematical implementation of surface-area and volume.
Reusable displayInfo method that keeps main method concise.
Code compiles and produces exact required output.
areas_for_improvement: Make the no-arg constructor delegate via this(1, 1, 1, "white") to satisfy the explicit specification.
Add JavaDoc comments for the class and each public method to improve maintainability.
Consider overriding toString() instead of a custom displayInfo() to separate logic from presentation.

misconceptions.name: Constructor chaining oversight
misconceptions.description: Student manually assigned default values in the no-arg constructor instead of using this(...) to invoke the 4-arg constructor, missing an explicit requirement.

evidence.note: Direct field assignments instead of calling this(1,1,1,"white") as rubric instructs.
